blog.name: rhaben
blog.title: Rhaben's Realm
blog.description: Welcome to my somewhat odd life.  I am an artist/designer/home schooling mom.  I love to draw, and look on the humble drawing as the basis of all art.  I also design cross stitch patterns and do a bit of needle felting.  Basically, I try my hand at everything.  I'm a bit of a geek, love scifi and fantasy, old movies/tv, love to read (just about all topics) and adore ALL animals.

summary: I really need to start a journal or a side blog or something to keep track of my dreams because some of them can get really...
body:
I really need to start a journal or a side blog or something to keep track of my dreams because some of them can get really weird.

Last night I dreamt I was in some James Bond type film, and I was the James Bond character. Only, no one was given scripts, and none of the actors were introduced to one another beforehand. So I never knew if I was interacting with a costar or an extra or someone who just happened to be in the area. At one point, we were supposed to film some chase scene, but I didn’t know who I was meant to be chasing because I hadn’t met the villain yet. So I just went and swam in a hotel pool, which I enjoyed, but I knew was probably not a good idea for the type of film I was in. People get killed in pools in movies like this, I thought.

But then suddenly all the water was out of the pool and I look up and there’s Michael Sheen standing by the edge, for some reason with Aziraphale’s hair, and he’s wearing some kind of medieval cloak over a normal suit. And he looks just as confused as I feel, and maybe he should be. He’s in an action movie with no fucking script, and he’s meeting the hero for the first time, who should be a tall, handsome, middle aged man, a well-known actor, but instead it’s some 5-foot-nothing 21-year-old girl.

I end up just laughing at the first sight of him, and he’s just like, “What?”

I say, “I don’t know what’s going on, but you’re…Michael Sheen. That’s so weird. Um. What are you wearing exactly?”

“Well what are you wearing?” he asks, pointing at my bathing suit.

“I wanted to swim.”

He just blinks and then starts looking around, but all the cameras are hidden and we also haven’t met the filming crew and directors, but somehow we understand they’re there at all times. So I get out and start looking with him.

“Are you the villain?” I ask after a few minutes, trying to make conversation.

“You can’t just ask that. What if it ends up in the film?”

“Film’s pretty stupid so far, so I doubt it matters. Are you the villain?”

“No.”

“What are you then?”

“Supposed to help you, I think.”

“Ah, that’s just what the villain would say if I’m not supposed to know who he is.”

He doesn’t say anything, and goes to move a plant, behind which we find a small camera. Then the door opens behind us and a man in a t-shirt and jeans, covered in electronic equipment, busts in and yells, “Cut.”

Then I woke up.

blog.name: fuckyeahgoodomens
blog.title: Fuck Yeah Good Omens
blog.description: Funniest apocalypse ever!

summary: Good Omens: All the signs are pointing to a great TV series
title: Good Omens: All the signs are pointing to a great TV series
excerpt: Neil Gaiman has adapted his and Terry Pratchett’s beloved joint novel for an Amazon Prime series starring Michael Sheen and David Tennant. Will the gods smile on this one?
description:
“I’m one of the people who read the book when it came out,” begins Sheen, in a chipper mood as we meet ahead of its long-awaited TV release. “For years, I really looked forward to some version of it being on television. So there’s a part of me that’s anticipating it as a fan.

“I didn’t know what I was getting into, because I didn’t read the book and wasn’t part of that existing fandom before I was involved,” says Tennant, representing the other part of their audience. “I have people come up to me saying it’s their favourite book and they have three copies in their house. You’re terrified that you’re carrying people’s dreams, that you can really ruin their day. But I’ve caught up with it since, and now I’ve seen it I’m back to just feeling excited. There’s nothing about this that precludes you if you don’t know Neil and Terry’s work, and I might regret saying this, but I’m currently quite confident that fans will be pleased.”

…

These names reflect a weighty production. Altogether, the first series involved 117 days of filming, 1,200 CGI shots, 200 speaking parts in all, and was set in 40 different periods, from the Garden of Eden to contemporary Soho.

A disproportionate amount of these periods are presented in a glorious 28-minute intro to the third episode, in which the friendship of Aziraphale and Crowley is documented throughout the ages.

“We got to dress up a bit, wearing ancient Greek togas, then a full suit of armour, and then we’re in Victorian era, so that was great fun to do,” recalls Sheen. “The filming was spread out through the shoot, so every now and then, we got to go, ‘oooh good, we get to do another one of those. French Revolution tomorrow!’”

28 minutes of Aziraphale and Crowley through the history of mankind!

blog.name: j-philly-b
blog.title: Yeah, so that happened...
blog.description: Always over-thinking plot and character motivations, and sometimes posting those thoughts; interspersed with random posts about work, life, and, from time to time, the Spanish Inquisition (bet you didn’t expect that!).

summary: Neil Gaiman, Michael Sheen, and Nick Offerman discussing Good Omens. More specifically, Neil Gaiman being very thoughtful and...
body: Neil Gaiman, Michael Sheen, and Nick Offerman discussing Good Omens. More specifically, Neil Gaiman being very thoughtful and funny discussing Good Omens, Michael Sheen giving a dramatic reading of a scene from the novel and making jokes, and Nick Offerman in monk’s robes infrequently asking questions in a deep and thoughtful tone while slipping in the occasional double entendre. Interrupted by two sneak peeks from the show. So glad I went.

blog.name: shersjar
blog.title: Bag-End, Underhill, Hobbiton
blog.description:
Nerd, reader, incurable dreamer, musical enthusiast, and a passenger spiritually on the road 24/7. This is a small corner of my life, where I store things that I find joy in.

***Disclaimer: the portrait is an illustration of Matilda at 30 by Quentin Blake. The header image features the cast of the BBC Radio Dramatization of Neverwhere. Welcome to London Below! (Psst. I probably won’t change the header image until the new sequel to Neverwhere comes out...)

summary: Read these sweet, hilarious, and heartwarming memories with Sir Ian McKellen shared by his dear friends and close colleagues in...
body:
Read these sweet, hilarious, and heartwarming memories with Sir Ian McKellen shared by his dear friends and close colleagues in the celebration of the legendary actor’s 80th birthday. They made my heart so full. I’ve never met Sir McKellen in person, let alone know him personally—though I’ve always loved the characters he’s portrayed on screens and his childlike smiles that are both adorable and stunning—but after reading this article, I feel like I have known the world renowned actor like an old friend. An essential read for fans.

Here are some extracts; read the full article on The Guardian [Link]:

Michael Sheen: “He’s not a mentor. He would never dare to tell anyone what to do. He has great humility and a very gentle way with people. He’s almost like an Alan Bennett character, though he sort of plays on that a bit because he’s very mischievous. I think it quite suits him at times to be a fairy godmother figure, knowing he’s got this roaring engine inside. He’s extremely sure of what he believes in, so much so he doesn’t need to push it on people. He’s very open and non-dogmatic. His confidence about how good he is gives him a “fuck you” quality. People are clearly not going to take his career away from him because he speaks his mind. He’s one of the greatest actors of all time and has proved he can do anything he wants. He’s an unstoppable force.”

Bill Condon: “In the flesh, he doesn’t seem anywhere near 80. He’s such a young spirit. On Gods and Monsters, the Whale movie, he’d shoot for 12 hours then ring me at 1am with notes. At the time he was also really embracing the movie star life. He had a wonderful house in the hills with a pool and a jacuzzi, and threw fun parties all the time. He does nothing with reserve or looking down his nose.”

Judi Dench: “He’s somebody who’s ever-present; a very good friend to me. I know that if I rang he would always make time to see me or be around or to be there with advice. It was lovely doing Cats [the forthcoming film of the musical] earlier this year. While he did his number, I was in an enormous cat basket. I had on a very big fur coat and nothing else. It was fantastic. I could have dropped off if I wanted. It was wonderful to just watch him working. He plays Gus the theatre cat and that’s perfect casting. He’s like no other animal I know. A rare beast.”

Anthony Hopkins: “He’s very funny. He made me laugh all the time with little camp in-jokes. I’d be acting my head off and he’d say: “Ooh, dear, get her.” In the theatre, it’s impossible to work with such people. I have to walk off the stage because I’m laughing so much.”

Derek Jacobi: “As an actor, he has an absolute focus on what he wants and how to get it. He is amazing with props. I remember in Richard III, in the wooing scene with Anne, he only had the use of one arm. And he kind of stripped off with that one arm, down to his bare chest, then gradually put his clothes back on. People were fixated on this one-handed striptease. It was very Ian: eye-catching, theatrical, riveting.”

Patrick Stewart: “We shot the first X-Men film in 2002 and I wasn’t absolutely ready to just fall into his arms. But we had adjoining luxury trailers and took to hanging out. Ian always had nice nibbles – pastries, nice things he’d made before he came to work. And we quickly found we had so much in common. He’s a Lancastrian and I’m a Yorkshireman; we are a year apart and grew up on opposite sides of the Pennines. We became very good friends. As well as X-Men, we have worked together a lot on stage. Sometimes I feel we’re enjoying it too much and the audience don’t quite understand why we’re having so much fun.”

Helen Mirren: “Every actor has a slightly different approach. Some reach their performance quickly, others take a long time. Ian likes to really explore all around the edges before he decides on the centre. He likes to leave it quite open and doesn’t hone it until quite late. He is absolutely masterful. I would stand in the wings and watch him: an extraordinary technician, so in control of the audience. It’s a miracle to see.”

Stephen Fry: “Incidentally, how great is he at comedy? A glorious panto dame – and stunningly hilarious in Chekhov’s Wild Honey. He’s the most delightful and entertaining friend anyone could ever have.”

Janet Suzman: “He is in the grand tradition, to this foreigner anyway, of that most English of creatures, Mr Mischief: camp, brilliantly talented, clever as paint, well educated. He went to Cambridge and read English as thousands of others have, but he put his degree to Good Use by getting to be an actor, one of those creatures who use the English language at its best practically all the time.”

Russell Tovey: “I started at the National when I was 19 and I remember the first time I heard about him. I was having vocal coaching with Patsy Rodenburg and we were sat on these chintzy couches. I said they were nice and she said they were donated by Ian. Then I saw him at events for Stonewall and the Terrence Higgins Trust. He has always been at the forefront of activism for gay rights and HIV/Aids. He’s a busy man but he finds the time to do it – then goes off to give an incredible performance in a play.”

— Extracts from “’I even loved his Twankey’: Dench, Hopkins, Mirren and more on Ian McKellen at 80” by Catherine Shoard and Chris Wiegand for The Guardian.

reblog.comment:

He’s almost like an Alan Bennett character, though he sort of plays on that a bit because he’s very mischievous. I think it quite suits him at times to be a fairy godmother figure, knowing he’s got this roaring engine inside. He’s extremely sure of what he believes in, so much so he doesn’t need to push it on people. He’s very open and non-dogmatic. His confidence about how good he is gives him a “fuck you” quality. People are clearly not going to take his career away from him because he speaks his mind. He’s one of the greatest actors of all time and has proved he can do anything he wants. He’s an unstoppable force.”

Bill Condon: “In the flesh, he doesn’t seem anywhere near 80. He’s such a young spirit. On Gods and Monsters, the Whale movie, he’d shoot for 12 hours then ring me at 1am with notes. At the time he was also really embracing the movie star life. He had a wonderful house in the hills with a pool and a jacuzzi, and threw fun parties all the time. He does nothing with reserve or looking down his nose.”

Judi Dench: “He’s somebody who’s ever-present; a very good friend to me. I know that if I rang he would always make time to see me or be around or to be there with advice. It was lovely doing Cats [the forthcoming film of the musical] earlier this year. While he did his number, I was in an enormous cat basket. I had on a very big fur coat and nothing else. It was fantastic. I could have dropped off if I wanted. It was wonderful to just watch him working. He plays Gus the theatre cat and that’s perfect casting. He’s like no other animal I know. A rare beast.”

Anthony Hopkins: “He’s very funny. He made me laugh all the time with little camp in-jokes. I’d be acting my head off and he’d say: “Ooh, dear, get her.” In the theatre, it’s impossible to work with such people. I have to walk off the stage because I’m laughing so much.”

Derek Jacobi: “As an actor, he has an absolute focus on what he wants and how to get it. He is amazing with props. I remember in Richard III, in the wooing scene with Anne, he only had the use of one arm. And he kind of stripped off with that one arm, down to his bare chest, then gradually put his clothes back on. People were fixated on this one-handed striptease. It was very Ian: eye-catching, theatrical, riveting.”

Patrick Stewart: “We shot the first X-Men film in 2002 and I wasn’t absolutely ready to just fall into his arms. But we had adjoining luxury trailers and took to hanging out. Ian always had nice nibbles – pastries, nice things he’d made before he came to work. And we quickly found we had so much in common. He’s a Lancastrian and I’m a Yorkshireman; we are a year apart and grew up on opposite sides of the Pennines. We became very good friends. As well as X-Men, we have worked together a lot on stage. Sometimes I feel we’re enjoying it too much and the audience don’t quite understand why we’re having so much fun.”

Helen Mirren: “Every actor has a slightly different approach. Some reach their performance quickly, others take a long time. Ian likes to really explore all around the edges before he decides on the centre. He likes to leave it quite open and doesn’t hone it until quite late. He is absolutely masterful. I would stand in the wings and watch him: an extraordinary technician, so in control of the audience. It’s a miracle to see.”

Stephen Fry: “Incidentally, how great is he at comedy? A glorious panto dame – and stunningly hilarious in Chekhov’s Wild Honey. He’s the most delightful and entertaining friend anyone could ever have.”

Janet Suzman: “He is in the grand tradition, to this foreigner anyway, of that most English of creatures, Mr Mischief: camp, brilliantly talented, clever as paint, well educated. He went to Cambridge and read English as thousands of others have, but he put his degree to Good Use by getting to be an actor, one of those creatures who use the English language at its best practically all the time.”

Russell Tovey: “I started at the National when I was 19 and I remember the first time I heard about him. I was having vocal coaching with Patsy Rodenburg and we were sat on these chintzy couches. I said they were nice and she said they were donated by Ian. Then I saw him at events for Stonewall and the Terrence Higgins Trust. He has always been at the forefront of activism for gay rights and HIV/Aids. He’s a busy man but he finds the time to do it – then goes off to give an incredible performance in a play.”

— Extracts from “’I even loved his Twankey’: Dench, Hopkins, Mirren and more on Ian McKellen at 80” by Catherine Shoard and Chris Wiegand for The Guardian.

trail.content_raw:
Read these sweet, hilarious, and heartwarming memories with Sir Ian McKellen shared by his dear friends and close colleagues in the celebration of the legendary actor’s 80th birthday. They made my heart so full. I’ve never met Sir McKellen in person, let alone know him personally—though I’ve always loved the characters he’s portrayed on screens and his childlike smiles that are both adorable and stunning—but after reading this article, I feel like I have known the world renowned actor like an old friend. An essential read for fans.

Here are some extracts; read the full article on The Guardian [Link]:

Michael Sheen: “He’s not a mentor. He would never dare to tell anyone what to do. He has great humility and a very gentle way with people. He’s almost like an Alan Bennett character, though he sort of plays on that a bit because he’s very mischievous. I think it quite suits him at times to be a fairy godmother figure, knowing he’s got this roaring engine inside. He’s extremely sure of what he believes in, so much so he doesn’t need to push it on people. He’s very open and non-dogmatic. His confidence about how good he is gives him a “fuck you” quality. He’s an unstoppable force.”

It was very Ian: eye-catching, theatrical, riveting.”

He went to Cambridge and read English as thousands of others have, but he put his degree to Good Use by getting to be an actor, one of those creatures who use the English language at its best practically all the time.”

Russell Tovey: “I started at the National when I was 19 and I remember the first time I heard about him. I was having vocal coaching with Patsy Rodenburg and we were sat on these chintzy couches. question: Michael Sheen or David Tennant?
answer: That’s a difficult question! I love them both so much! I’ve known about Michael Sheen for a longer amount of time since my mother is a fan of him as well. So maybe him? I don’t know.
